title: Aging With MS

content: Aging with MS is not much fun.

When I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS) about 40 years ago, my doctor told me what to expect. “You will get worse until your 60s,” he said. “Then the MS will stop. At that point, unfortunately, aging will kick in and continue to take you downhill.”

There were no medications claiming to slow the disease then, and the doctor turned out to be mostly right. I’m in a mobility scooter now, and at 75, aging is really kicking in big time. My life is shrinking. Because it’s rainy and cold, I sometimes go days without getting out of the apartment building.
Aging has its benefits, like MS does. People don’t expect as much of you; they are willing to do things for you. But like with MS, the downsides outweigh the benefits most of the time.

I notice these downsides more when I’m visiting older friends who don’t have MS. I notice they forget things they knew the last time we spoke. Sometimes, they say things that just don’t make much sense, or things that are completely unrealistic.

content: Cognitive issues like those can come at any time with MS, but I notice them more often in old people, and I wonder: “Am I doing that too?” Am I making sense or not? In talking with people I trust, like my children, I sometimes ask them if I’m making sense, or if I’m repeating myself, another thing old people do. They usually say I’m making sense to them, but I still wonder.

My wife Aisha has been with me through this whole 40-year journey. She has often told me that MS looks to her just like aging super-fast. Just as with aging, we slow down; we lose mobility; we might lose coordination or hand dexterity. We have cognitive lapses, forgetting things or getting them wrong.
The National Multiple Sclerosis Society (NMSS) says people with MS do age faster, with a biological age 1.4 years older on average than their birth year would indicate.

content: At this point, I don’t know what’s aging and what’s MS, and I kind of think it doesn’t matter. Either way, we have to figure out how to cope, and try to help our bodies as best we can. I find I need to rest more, and I have to be OK with that.

content: Twenty years ago, in my book The Art of Getting Well, I described a 5-step healing path of slowing down, setting priorities, educating oneself, getting help, and putting our bodies’ needs first. In 2026, it feels like those steps apply to aging well.

It can be sad not being able to do things I think are important and would love to do, but there’s no sense pretending I’m not old or not disabled. I have to constantly focus on what I can actually do and how to do it effectively and safely. To the extent that I stay mindful about my life situation, I can do enough to make me feel life is worth living. When I try to overdo or go too fast, things fall apart.

It’s kind of a drag when being old with MS starts to feel like a cage. It’s pouring rain now in San Francisco, where I live. When I was 45 and mobile, I would have been out doing things, but as it is, I hardly ever go out.

content: I could put on warm clothes and rain gear, put a plastic liner over my handlebars to protect the scooter, and go out, but I’ve been choosing to keep comfortable and safe. It’s an old person’s decision, living virtually. I don’t know what’s happening in my own neighborhood, but I’m keeping up with what’s happening in Venezuela.

The older we get, the more important self-care becomes. We’re at risk. NMSS says that other conditions we’re more likely to develop as we age can have an outsized impact on people with MS. Things like diabetes, cardiovascular disease, or blood vessel disease can “change the structure of the brain.” Then we have to deal with MS brain changes along with new injuries. So stay as healthy as you can.

content: Their website points out other conditions that often go along with MS, including depression, anxiety, high cholesterol, and lung disease. These also go along with aging, but they can be treated. If we live long enough with MS, we get to experience the shadow side of life in depth, both in ourselves and others. Hopefully, we can react by showing compassion for ourselves and others, and appreciating the joys that life can still bring.

content: We’re lucky, really. Living into our 70s and 80s with MS makes us lucky compared to previous generations of MS patients. People used to be bedridden by their 50s and dead around 60. Exercising and eating well enables us to live a healthier life, while antibiotics keep people from dying young of pneumonia and urinary tract infections, which used to kill MSers off young.

So it could be worse. I am making a list of things to remember while aging with MS. Ask for help, let go of unnecessary things, focus on one thing at a time, exercise, help others when I realistically can, stop worrying, and choose to be happy.
